questions.answer: Islam is the religion of peace and submission to Allah, based on the Quran and teachings of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).
Allah is the one true God, the Creator of everything, most merciful and compassionate.
The Quran is the holy book of Islam, revealed to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) over 23 years, guiding Muslims in faith and practice.
Salah is the five daily prayers which are mandatory for Muslims to maintain their connection with Allah.
Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) is the final messenger of Allah, who delivered the Quran and showed the perfect example of how to live.
Hadith are recorded sayings, actions, and approvals of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), which guide Muslims in understanding and practicing Islam.
Zakat is a mandatory form of charity in Islam, requiring Muslims to give a portion of their wealth to help the needy.
Fasting during the month of Ramadan is one of the five pillars of Islam, where Muslims abstain from food, drink, and other invalidators from dawn until sunset.
Hajj is the pilgrimage to Mecca that every Muslim must perform at least once in their lifetime, if physically and financially able.
Tawheed is the Islamic belief in the oneness and uniqueness of Allah, rejecting any partners or equals.
Halal means lawful or permissible according to Islamic law.
Haram means forbidden or prohibited by Islamic law.
Islam commands speaking the truth, standing for justice, and acting with integrity in all affairs.
Dua for guidance includes prayers like Istikhara, asking Allah to guide towards what is best.
Muslims say 'peace be upon him' (PBUH) or send salutations (salawat) whenever mentioning Prophet Muhammad to show respect.
